Sullivan: Cauley-Stein the biggest of the bigs

Wildcats' center has career-high 21 points, plus 12 rebounds, five steals, three blocks

Sullivan: Cauley-Stein the biggest of the bigs

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 12:42 a.m. EST December 6, 2014

UK's Willie Cauley-Stein makes one of three blocks to go with a career-high 21 points, 12 rebounds and five steals.(Photo: By Mike Weaver, Special to the CJ)

1 CONNECT 9 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. Between his wrist and his elbow, Willie Cauley-Stein's right arm bears a tattoo that reads, "The greatest pleasure in life is doing what others say you cannot do."

His problem, going forward, will be finding something that fits that description.

The University of Kentucky's freakishly athletic 7-footer did about all you could ask and more than you could expect in Friday's 63-51 slugfest against sixth-ranked Texas. He scored a career-high 21 points, and led all of the game's contestants with 12 rebounds, five steals and three blocked shots.

"He affected the game," Texas coach Rick Barnes said, "every way you can affect it."

Though he did not juggle chainsaws or sing arias or perform quadratic equations, Cauley-Stein approached awesome in so many basketball respects that UK coach John Calipari was compelled to make an exception to his platoon system that echoed George Orwell.

Video | John Calipari on the win against Texas

"All animals are equal," Orwell wrote in Animal Farm, "but some animals are more equal than others."

Instead of distributing minutes on a semi-socialistic basis, as he had done in previous games, Calipari pulled forward Marcus Lee aside at halftime and informed him of UK's new reality. On this night, at least, Cauley-Stein was not taking turns but taking over. He would ultimately play 33 minutes seven more than any Kentucky player had logged in the Wildcats' first seven games and he would likely have played more had he not developed a cramp in his right left while diving on the floor.

"Don't think I got away from platoons," Calipari protested. "I didn't. Just Willie played so well, we had some foul problems, someone plays well you kind of slide them in on another platoon. I talked to Marcus Lee after. He said, 'Coach, I'm good. Willie was so good today, I accept it.' "

Sometimes, a proud player has to acknowledge when a teammate has surpassed him. Sometimes, a struggling team needs a veteran player to step forward in a tight spot and lead the way to salvation. Without Cauley-Stein's contributions Friday night, the top-rated Wildcats would likely have lost. They had a hard enough time winning with him.

MORE: Cats hand Longhorns first loss

MORE: Game Rewind | Cauley-Stein, UK knock off Texas

In a game Barnes referred to as "big-boy" basketball, 51 fouls were called and numerous others were ignored as incidental contact. Kentucky was outrebounded, 42-31, and missed its first 11 three-point shots. It survived on Texas' 20 turnovers and by managing foul problems that cost the Longhorns their starting center, Cameron Ridley, and 6-11 freshman Myles Turner.

Cauley-Stein was primarily responsible for both players fouling out, and made nine of the 12 free throws that resulted from Texas reaching. For a giant known more as a finesse player than a dominating force, Cauley-Stein stepped out of character and onto throats. On this night, he appeared to be as comfortable in the post as he usually does on the perimeter.

"I think I just finally accepted that I've gotta do that," Cauley-Stein said. "I've gotta do that stuff for our team, and work on the other stuff outside of it. Just get really good at doing that and the other stuff will just come.

Video | UK's Cauley-Stein on Texas win

"That's one of the biggest reasons why I came back (as a junior) is just to develop myself more as a basketball player. And I feel like I'm starting to do that. The good thing is I've got so much more time. Like, it's only December. I've still got like three months of this."

There are still things he can do better, of course, but they amount to minor details and not major issues.

"The biggest thing I'm working on him with our people (is) he's got to come to wide bases when he comes to a stop," Calipari said. "When his feet are really close, he's just got no balance and he just flops around. When he comes to that wide base, he's 7-foot and he just jumps over the game. He reaches up, literally he's shooting the ball and he's above the square (on the backboard) shooting down."

When he gets that stuff straightened out, perhaps Willie Cauley-Stein should look into tattoo removal.
